story:
¿Qué?

La amistad y el amor dan fuerzas a los personajes de El billete dorado para luchar contra la injusticia.

Un grupo de alumnos de instituto, que han acosado a un alumno y a un profesor, se suben a un tren para asistir a un concierto en Madrid. Sin embargo, por culpa de un extravagante científico ruso, son transportados al París ocupado por los nazis justo dos días antes de la Gran Redada de judíos. Algunos alumnos se convierten en agentes de la Gestapo, otros en judíos y otros en miembros de la Resistencia.

El objetivo de los protagonistas de la novela será doble. Por un lado, encontrar a todos sus compañeros judíos y, en especial a David, el alumno acosado, en paradero desconocido desde que fue detenido por los alemanes, y, por otro, localizar el mágico billete dorado que les permitirá regresar a sus casas en el presente.

¿Quiénes?

Tandaia es una editorial con voluntad de cambio, de dar la alternativa a autores que no la encuentran en otro lugar, con nuevas y refrescantes ideas como es el emplear una campaña preventa para valorar la aceptación y viabilidad de cada título.

De este modo eres tú, ahora que te estás planteando cómo colaborar, el que decide si la obra que te presentamos verá la luz pasando a formar parte de nuestro catálogo... porque consideramos al lector parte fundamental del proceso.

Hoy os presentamos a Miguel Ángel Viciana.

Nacido en Almería en 1959, es doctor en Filología Hispánica y trabaja actualmente como profesor de instituto. Su producción como escritor es amplia y variada e incluye la poesía, el ensayo, la novela y el relato, aparte de algunas publicaciones de carácter educativo. Ya antes de escribir El billete dorado, había demostrado su destreza en la recreación de acontecimientos y ambientes históricos. Ejemplos de ello son los relatos «La Rebeca» (basado en un hecho real y situado en la construcción de  los refugios antiaéreos de Almería) o «La leyenda de Basti» (relato juvenil situado en la época de los íberos).

Para conocer al autor en su faceta de profesor, se puede visitar la web Gran Orator (http://www.granorator.com);  en su faceta de aficionado a la astronomía en la web Nombres del Universo (http://www.nombresuniverso.com) y en la de escritor en la web Miguel Ángel Viciana (http://miguelangelviciana.com).

¿Por qué?

Y por aquí una muestra de lo que encontraréis en sus páginas:

«No hubo tiempo de sentir miedo. Al salir del túnel, el tren recuperó la normalidad. La niebla había desaparecido y se habían encendido las luces. La única diferencia era que el traqueteo del tren, que apenas se notaba habitualmente, ahora semejaba al de un tren antiguo. El tren disminuyó la marcha hasta detenerse en una parada.
            —¡Mirad! —gritó Pedro.
            —¡Están rodando una película! —subrayó Ana, su novia.
            No era una parada normal, sino un apeadero en el que destacaba un edificio con tejas grises. Por las ventanas de la derecha observamos varios soldados alemanes de la Segunda Guerra Mundial, algunos de los cuales llevaban perros en actitud vigilante. También había algunos civiles que vestían con trajes de la misma época. Reparé en que las telas de los vestidos estaban peor planchadas de lo habitual. Pensé que el director de la película habría exigido que, para mayor realismo, se utilizasen tejidos originales.
            Por la ventana de la izquierda contemplamos los típicos vagones de ganado que transportaban judíos a los campos de concentración. De algunas estrechas ranuras salían también las típicas manos de los judíos, lo único que indicaba que dentro había seres humanos. Una mano femenina tiró un papel doblado cuidadosamente. Un ferroviario lo recogió y, disimuladamente, lo introdujo en su bolsillo. Supongo que se trataría de un mensaje para algún familiar.
            Intenté descubrir dónde se hallaban situadas las cámaras del rodaje sin conseguirlo. No se distinguía tampoco la parafernalia habitual de los rodajes. Algún compañero quiso hacer alguna fotografía con su móvil, pero no le funcionaba. Nuestro tren se puso en marcha de nuevo.
            Me entró un gran sopor y me dormí. Me desperté al disminuir la marcha del tren. Mi mente registraba imágenes, olores y ruidos que era incapaz de procesar. A mi lado estaba sentado David con la cabeza inclinada. Me pareció muy agobiado. Abrieron la puerta del vagón con energía. Entró un oficial alemán seguido de un soldado armado con una metralleta. En sus gorras destacaba una pequeña calavera.
            —¡Heil Hitler! —me saludaron estirando enérgicamente el brazo con la palma abierta hacia abajo»

¿Cómo?

Para arrancar el proyecto nos hemos fijado como objetivo 880€; esta es la cantidad que recaudaríamos si alrededor de cincuenta mecenas se hiciesen, cada cual, con un ejemplar de esta primera edición.

  • Teniendo acceso a las galeradas de edición.
  • Recibiendo un ejemplar semanas antes de la salida al mercado de la obra.
  • Si bien, también podrías ver tu nombre en los agradecimientos aportando un poco más.

Los fondos recaudados, se utilizarán como ayuda para sacar adelante esta primera edición de El billete dorado que saldría después a la venta.

Además...

Sabemos que son tiempos difíciles, también nosotros los sufrimos, y es posible que no te encuentres en disposición de apoyarnos con tu mecenazgo en estos momentos... pero esperamos que si esto te ha llegado al alma, incluso si tal vez conoces en persona al autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-oreja... ) para que alcancemos nuestra meta y Miguel Ángel Viciana vea publicada su obra.

Gracias por vuestro tiempo.
story_txt:
¿Qué?
La amistad y el amor dan fuerzas a los personajes de El billete dorado para luchar contra la injusticia.
Un grupo de alumnos de instituto, que han acosado a un alumno y a un profesor, se suben a un tren para asistir a un concierto en Madrid. Sin embargo, por culpa de un extravagante científico ruso, son transportados al París ocupado por los nazis justo dos días antes de la Gran Redada de judíos. Algunos alumnos se convierten en agentes de la Gestapo, otros en judíos y otros en miembros de la Resistencia.
El objetivo de los protagonistas de la novela será doble. Por un lado, encontrar a todos sus compañeros judíos y, en especial a David, el alumno acosado, en paradero desconocido desde que fue detenido por los alemanes, y, por otro, localizar el mágico billete dorado que les permitirá regresar a sus casas en el presente.
¿Quiénes?
Tandaia es una editorial con voluntad de cambio, de dar la alternativa a autores que no la encuentran en otro lugar, con nuevas y refrescantes ideas como es el emplear una campaña preventa para valorar la aceptación y viabilidad de cada título.
De este modo eres tú, ahora que te estás planteando cómo colaborar, el que decide si la obra que te presentamos verá la luz pasando a formar parte de nuestro catálogo... porque consideramos al lector parte fundamental del proceso.
Hoy os presentamos a Miguel Ángel Viciana.
Nacido en Almería en 1959, es doctor en Filología Hispánica y trabaja actualmente como profesor de instituto. Su producción como escritor es amplia y variada e incluye la poesía, el ensayo, la novela y el relato, aparte de algunas publicaciones de carácter educativo. Ya antes de escribir El billete dorado, había demostrado su destreza en la recreación de acontecimientos y ambientes históricos. Ejemplos de ello son los relatos «La Rebeca» (basado en un hecho real y situado en la construcción de  los refugios antiaéreos de Almería) o «La leyenda de Basti» (relato juvenil situado en la época de los íberos).
Para conocer al autor en su faceta de profesor, se puede visitar la web Gran Orator (http://www.granorator.com);  en su faceta de aficionado a la astronomía en la web Nombres del Universo (http://www.nombresuniverso.com) y en la de escritor en la web Miguel Ángel Viciana (http://miguelangelviciana.com).
¿Por qué?
Y por aquí una muestra de lo que encontraréis en sus páginas:
«No hubo tiempo de sentir miedo. Al salir del túnel, el tren recuperó la normalidad. La niebla había desaparecido y se habían encendido las luces. También había algunos civiles que vestían con trajes de la misma época. Reparé en que las telas de los vestidos estaban peor planchadas de lo habitual. Pensé que el director de la película habría exigido que, para mayor realismo, se utilizasen tejidos originales.            Por la ventana de la izquierda contemplamos los típicos vagones de ganado que transportaban judíos a los campos de concentración. De algunas estrechas ranuras salían también las típicas manos de los judíos, lo único que indicaba que dentro había seres humanos. Una mano femenina tiró un papel doblado cuidadosamente. Un ferroviario lo recogió y, disimuladamente, lo introdujo en su bolsillo. Supongo que se trataría de un mensaje para algún familiar.            Intenté descubrir dónde se hallaban situadas las cámaras del rodaje sin conseguirlo. No se distinguía tampoco la parafernalia habitual de los rodajes. Algún compañero quiso hacer alguna fotografía con su móvil, pero no le funcionaba. Nuestro tren se puso en marcha de nuevo.            Me entró un gran sopor y me dormí. Me desperté al disminuir la marcha del tren. Mi mente registraba imágenes, olores y ruidos que era incapaz de procesar. A mi lado estaba sentado David con la cabeza inclinada. Me pareció muy agobiado. Abrieron la puerta del vagón con energía. Entró un oficial alemán seguido de un soldado armado con una metralleta. En sus gorras destacaba una pequeña calavera.            —¡Heil Hitler! —me saludaron estirando enérgicamente el brazo con la palma abierta hacia abajo»
¿Cómo?

Teniendo acceso a las galeradas de edición.
Recibiendo un ejemplar semanas antes de la salida al mercado de la obra.
Si bien, también podrías ver tu nombre en los agradecimientos aportando un poco más.

Los fondos recaudados, se utilizarán como ayuda para sacar adelante esta primera edición de El billete dorado que saldría después a la venta.
Además...

story:
I gave up my son because he was black.

Don’t get me wrong.  My child’s race made absolutely no difference to me.

But it made a big difference to society. 

It was 1970 and the civil rights movement was in full swing.  But I was to learn that liberal sentiments only went so far when it came to race in the bedroom—much less in the nursery.

I was an unwed teenager in a middle-class white world.  To fight for civil rights was one thing.  But to be pregnant by a black man was going too far.

I was abandoned by most of my friends, my family, and by the father.

So I did what everyone expected I should do.  I gave my baby up for adoption, even though I desperately wanted to keep him.

And then my life turned into the stuff of nightmares.

I married my baby’s father several years later and had another son, and then plunged into a life of secrets, lies, and abuse.

Plagued by my white guilt for giving up my black son, I stayed with their father for years. 

But throughout those years, I could never forget the baby I’d given up. 

And through an extraordinary set of circumstances, I found him before he could find me.

And now I’m ready to tell my story. 

My memoir, White Lady, Black Sons, is about the painful decisions I made in a world that wasn’t quite ready for integration in the household. 

It’s a memoir about changing race relations, and changing gender relations as I grew from a subservient and abused wife into a confident, assertive woman and writer. 

But I still need help. 

I need your help in bringing my story to light.

$3000 will enable me to edit my book and pay for layout, cover design and publication costs.  I don’t have the money to pay these costs myself, but with your help, my memoir can be in your hands. 

Please join my team and share in the rewards of turning one mother’s story into a universal story of our changing times.  Thank you so much for your support.  I’m excited to have accomplished my dream of writing a book and in sharing it with you.

story:
Why write Scratch, Crackle and Pop?

 

As I spend more time presenting my films at workshops, master classes and retrospectives, I field an ever-increasing amount of questions from my peers concerning the technique of painting and scratching on film. I would like to create a book to make these processes available to artists, students, teachers and the general public. Publishing a “manual” of handmade animation film techniques titled, Scratch, Crackle and Pop: A whole grain approach to making films without a camera will highlight 30 years of aesthetic discoveries that I have made in super–8, 16 mm and 35 mm animated/experimental film production. To enrich the reader’s understanding of my process, I will enclose a DVD compilation of short films that I have created between 1982 and 2011. 

There exist a very limited number of books on handmade film. There are even fewer practical “guidebooks”on the subject of handmade film techniques. In 2010, I decided to self-publish my first filmmaking cookbook, Recipes For Reconstruction: The Cookbook for the Frugal Filmmaker. This do-it-yourself manual not only helped me promote my visibility in the field of cameraless filmmaking, it also reminded me how few artist books exist to inspire experimental filmmakers.[1] 

This second instructional book is intended to convince developing artists to try simple, inexpensive handmade filmmaking before it becomes extinct. To many people who may only know the name of Norman McLaren, this book of will introduce established international names such as Len Lye from New Zealand, Harry Smith from The United States as well as Barber Neubauer and Pierre Hebert – and new techniques such as batiking and bleaching directly onto the surface of the film. This book will also help me to cross language barriers and talk at greater length about my processes to an international audience. 

 Technical Layout: 

Scratch, Crackle and Pop will be divided into three distinctive sections. Each part will highlight the qualities and characteristics of a particular technique that I’ve used in my process (i.e. scratching, painting and brikolage) and will include a list the tools and tips for creating a successful film. Hand–drawn diagrams, film stills and photographs will also be added to support the physical production steps. Each chapter will also reference the films on the accompanying DVD. Mr. Marco DeBlois, the animation curator from the Cinematheque Quebecoise has graciously agreed both curate and edit the book for historical accuracy. As guest writer and curator, Mr. DeBlois’ chief responsibilities will ensure that the book provides a focused attention on the methodology of hand made filmmaking – a style of filmmaking where Quebec is has become a historical Mecca. 

Title: "Scratch, Crackle and Pop: The Whole grains approach to making films without a camera."  

Estimated retail price: $50.00 

Pages: aprox. 200 

Binding: perfect bound, colour and black and white 

[1] A few stand out, such as Stan Brakhage’s Giving and Taking Book [1971], Helen Hill’s Recipes For Disaster [2001] and To Boldly Go [2008. Worm Collective]. As an artist, these books pushed my constant curiosity and it inspired me to discover handmade films.

story:
Book: The Bomb Boys

Save a Hand, Save a Life, and Help Prevent the Next Tragedy

James Glencoe completely blew off his left hand with TATP, and injured his right.

James Glencoe was 16 and loved chemistry.  As with nearly all boys who love chemistry, eventually his nose turned to explosives.  He made something called TATP – triacetone triperoxide.

TATP is so powerful and unstable that Islamic terrorists call it “Mother of Satan.”  American high school kids call it fun.  After three days of synthesis, James had created about 20 grams—the weight of about four US quarters—and walked into his parents’ bedroom to show off his creation.

There, in front his mother, father, and girlfriend, his Mother of Satan lived up to its reputation: James blew off his left hand and damaged his right.  The specific cause of the explosion remains a mystery.

Kids today are making explosives like never before.  They are blowing themselves and their friends to pieces with homemade “fireworks.”

A small percentage turn violent and use them to attack.  The 1999 Columbine killers used 95 bombs in their horrific rampage.  Eric Harris, in particular, should have easily been caught in advance.  There is a chance that the Columbine attack would have been interrupted if only there had been a reputable, accurate book available on how to recognize these dangers. I have written that book. It is entitled The Bomb Boys, and it may help to prevent the next national tragedy—if I can get the funding to produce and distribute it.

High school kids in 2013 are far more advanced at making explosives than those in 1999, regularly making extremely lethal concoctions such as HMTD (which most adults and even Soldiers never have heard of).  The Internet has facilitated a turbo-charge into the learning process.  As for TATP, it has caught on due to the ease of synthesis.  The unpredictability, power, and concealability of this high explosive that looks like table sugar makes gunpowder look tame by comparison.  Yet TATP is just one of many.

So we have these issues to consider:

1) Kids are burning down their homes and blowing themselves and others to pieces, by accident and on purpose.

2) Many victims who are injured physically or economically have no involvement with the activity.  Parents are being charged with felonies and getting successfully sued for their children’s “fireworks” that often cause fatalities.  This can be life-altering for anyone and a career-ender for professionals.

3) Good kids are being convicted of life-changing felonies for more trivial devices, many of which are simple like dry ice, acid, and Drano “bombs.”  None of these contain explosives.   Cases occur daily.  Last week, five boys, aged 13 to 15, were charged with “criminal use of a weapon of mass destruction,” a Class C felony in Kentucky, carrying a possible 5 – 10-year sentence, for a chemical “bomb.”  I have never heard of a fatality from a chemical pressure bomb—a “weapon of mass destruction.”  Yes, fatalities can happen, but “pressure bombs” are far from WMD.  Roman candles are more perilous.

4) Trauma from real explosives is horrific, making gunshot wounds look like bee stings.  James’ mom is suffering PTSD after watching her son blow his hands across the bedroom.  Many victims also suffer PTSD, not to mention blindness, a life without arms, and prison.

5) Community disruptions occur, causing school evacuations and commercial losses.

6) Kids are bringing explosives such as TATP and pipe bombs to school and to parties, often just to show friends.  A golf ball-sized volume of TATP in a pants pocket will blow off a leg.  Last week, a couple of men blew off three of their hands with a small amount of TATP in Australia.

7) Kids who survive bomb accidents are charged with homicide when members in their group are killed, even when the victims were willing participants.  Most injuries occur during play, while others are malicious, such as the recent Australian case wherein teenagers tossed a “golf ball bomb” to a 15-year-old with Asperger’s Syndrome.  The bomb amputated fingers and terribly damaged his hands.

8) Kids are making sensitive high explosives that can pass through nearly all detection.  Future criminals and terrorists will be more potent.  This is a global issue with massive security implications at home and abroad.  We already see it with countless bombs exploding each day.

9) School attacks are common.  The next Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold might kill hundreds of children.  This would be difficult to achieve with firearms, but with current homemade explosives, killing hundreds is possible.

Young victim of car bomb who died soon after.  (Mosul, Iraq.)

This has strategic, global implications.  The Boston pressure-cooker bombs are trivial compared to what some current high school sophomores can make.  What is in store for 2020 is anyone’s guess.

The trajectory is clear: innocent experimenters will be blown higher and higher into the treetops, while murderers will never have been so empowered.

My book teaches how to catch the juvenile bomb-makers and much more.  By the time educators or parents finish reading The Bomb Boys, they will easily be able to identify most “Bomb Boys,” typically through nothing more than conversation, and when that fails, physical evidence.  Experimenters and perpetrators follow a number of recognizable patterns, and most have equally recognizable personality traits.

List of Chapters:

About the Author: This is my fourth book.  I have published approximately 800 articles, mostly from overseas work in countries such as Iraq and Afghanistan.  My work is frequently picked up in other books, magazines, radio and television.  While in the Army Special Forces, I received specialized IED training, and as a kid, I was a Bomb Boy.

ENDORSEMENTS from previous work:

“He’s fearless…provides a candid, soldier’s-eye view…from the very unique perspective of being there with them for week and months at a time…delving
deep into the human component.” —General David H. Petraeus, former commander of Coalition forces in Iraq and Afghanistan, and Director of CIA

“Michael Yon’s voice is the voice of the soldier, often unfazed by what he sees, mission-focused and battle-hardened.  These guys don’t scare easily, and they never let up, and Michael tells the story from their point of view.” —Brian Williams, Anchor, NBC Nightly News

“Cuts through the fog of war…vivid…shocking and mesmerizing.” —The Boston Herald

“Yon covers soldiers…the old-fashioned way: He goes down the back alleys and the bad roads.” —Joe Galloway, Author of We were Soldiers Once…And Young

“…racked up more time embedded with combat units than any other journalist.” —New York Times

“…I haven’t seen anything quite like the coverage in Michael Yon’s dispatches from Mosul…compelling narrative.” —Michael Barone, US News and World Report

“His readers have learned what most Americans would not know from NBC, ABC, CBS, PBS, and NPR.” —Clifford May, former New York Times foreign correspondent

“Michael Yon brings it….If you want to know what is going on in this war, read him.” —Thomas E. Ricks, author of Fiasco, The Generals, and former military correspondent for The Washington Post

“…infuriated his military handlers, even as [he] gave American soldiers a robust new voice.” —Los Angeles Times

“And I reminded myself of something a writer friend, Michael Yon, once said to me, ‘Whenever the writing gets hard, it’s because your research is lacking.  Get back to digging and learning.  Then the words will flow.’” —Matthew Glencoe in the upcoming book, My Brother in Arms, the Inspiring Life of Mark Andrew Forester, and father of James Glencoe

Where we need to go from here:

My book is largely complete but there is much work to do.  This has been a monumental task.  I need $150,000 to polish the book, build a dedicated website, and hire a PR company.

6) Kids are bringing explosives such as TATP and pipe bombs to school and to parties, often just to show friends.  A golf ball-sized volume of TATP in a pants pocket will blow off a leg.  Last week, a couple of men blew off three of their hands with a small amount of TATP in Australia.
7) Kids who survive bomb accidents are charged with homicide when members in their group are killed, even when the victims were willing participants.  Most injuries occur during play, while others are malicious, such as the recent Australian case wherein teenagers tossed a “golf ball bomb” to a 15-year-old with Asperger’s Syndrome.  The bomb amputated fingers and terribly damaged his hands.
8) Kids are making sensitive high explosives that can pass through nearly all detection.  Future criminals and terrorists will be more potent.  This is a global issue with massive security implications at home and abroad.  We already see it with countless bombs exploding each day.
9) School attacks are common.  The next Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold might kill hundreds of children.  This would be difficult to achieve with firearms, but with current homemade explosives, killing hundreds is possible.
Young victim of car bomb who died soon after.  (Mosul, Iraq.)
This has strategic, global implications.  The Boston pressure-cooker bombs are trivial compared to what some current high school sophomores can make.  What is in store for 2020 is anyone’s guess.
The trajectory is clear: innocent experimenters will be blown higher and higher into the treetops, while murderers will never have been so empowered.
My book teaches how to catch the juvenile bomb-makers and much more.  By the time educators or parents finish reading The Bomb Boys, they will easily be able to identify most “Bomb Boys,” typically through nothing more than conversation, and when that fails, physical evidence.  Experimenters and perpetrators follow a number of recognizable patterns, and most have equally recognizable personality traits.
List of Chapters:



About the Author: This is my fourth book.  I have published approximately 800 articles, mostly from overseas work in countries such as Iraq and Afghanistan.  My work is frequently picked up in other books, magazines, radio and television.  While in the Army Special Forces, I received specialized IED training, and as a kid, I was a Bomb Boy.
ENDORSEMENTS from previous work:
“He’s fearless…provides a candid, soldier’s-eye view…from the very unique perspective of being there with them for week and months at a time…delvingdeep into the human component.” —General David H. Petraeus, former commander of Coalition forces in Iraq and Afghanistan, and Director of CIA
“Michael Yon’s voice is the voice of the soldier, often unfazed by what he sees, mission-focused and battle-hardened.  These guys don’t scare easily, and they never let up, and Michael tells the story from their point of view.” —Brian Williams, Anchor, NBC Nightly News
“Cuts through the fog of war…vivid…shocking and mesmerizing.” —The Boston Herald

“Yon covers soldiers…the old-fashioned way: He goes down the back alleys and the bad roads.” —Joe Galloway, Author of We were Soldiers Once…And Young
“…racked up more time embedded with combat units than any other journalist.” —New York Times
“…I haven’t seen anything quite like the coverage in Michael Yon’s dispatches from Mosul…compelling narrative.” —Michael Barone, US News and World Report
“His readers have learned what most Americans would not know from NBC, ABC, CBS, PBS, and NPR.” —Clifford May, former New York Times foreign correspondent
“Michael Yon brings it….If you want to know what is going on in this war, read him.” —Thomas E. Ricks, author of Fiasco, The Generals, and former military correspondent for The Washington Post
“…infuriated his military handlers, even as [he] gave American soldiers a robust new voice.” —Los Angeles Times
“And I reminded myself of something a writer friend, Michael Yon, once said to me, ‘Whenever the writing gets hard, it’s because your research is lacking.  Get back to digging and learning.  Then the words will flow.’” —Matthew Glencoe in the upcoming book, My Brother in Arms, the Inspiring Life of Mark Andrew Forester, and father of James Glencoe

Where we need to go from here:
My book is largely complete but there is much work to do.  This has been a monumental task.  I need $150,000 to polish the book, build a dedicated website, and hire a PR company.

story:
Our Story

Who:  I'm N.E. Francis, a national arts & entertainment journalist, and I'd like to tell you a little about myself and my new book, In Her Words: 25 Interviews with Kick-Ass Women in Arts & Entertainment. 

As an A & E journalist and celebrity interviewer for over 15 years, I've met and spoken with some of our generation's most vibrant, important and insanely talented people.  But there are a group of women artists--nearly 30 singers, writers, actors, musicians and more--who are so smart, so gifted and so incredibly relevant, that America really needs to know more about them.

In Her Words contains my top 25 favorite interviews with outstanding women artists of today, including interviews with singer/songwriter Linda Perry, feminist playwright Carolyn Gage, film maker Katherine Brooks, artist/poet Dr. Marie Cartier and authors Linda Andersson and Sara Marx, and music group Sugarbeach, among many others.  Each interview and woman chosen for In Her Words has either inspired me, challenged me or flat-out changed my life's trajectory.  I believe that their stories will do the same for you.

I'd also like to introduce you to In Her Word's amazing artist, Jeremy Enslow.  Jeremy is a young, contemporary artist out of Minneapolis who describes his artistic approach as "exaggerated caricature-style, not quite abstract, just allowing each piece to take on its own form."  The former Bank of America Achievement of Fine Art recipient favors spray paint and acrylics for personal art and oils for most commissions.  He utilized spray paint and acrylics on vellum paper for In Her Word's cover art (see cropped image above), and ink, charcoals, color pencils and watercolors for the inside portraits.

What: In Her Words: 25 Interviews with Kick-Ass Women in Arts & Entertainment is a hand-picked collection of interviews by National Progressive Arts & Entertainment reporter N. E. Francis with some of the most talented, cutting-edge women in arts and entertainment today--and why you should get to know them.  The author shares her private thoughts on each interview and when it happened, plus how each artist inspired and transformed her.


In Her Words also contains exclusive, dramatic art by award-winning Minneapolis artist, Jeremy Enslow, that will blow our readers away.


When:  In Her Words will be published by September 1, 2011 or earlier, depending on the fruits of this fundraising campaign.  The more donations, the sooner the book will be published and released.  Let's make it happen!

The Impact:

First and foremost, it is my intention and deepest hope that In Her Words will engage, inspire and change the trajectory of many readers' lives, as well as turn you on to some "kick-ass" women and their art.


A portion of the net proceeds from In Her Words will also be privately donated to various women's and LGBT charities that inspire the author and artist.


You give; we give; and the world's a better place.  This is what it's all about.


What We Need & What You Get:

Publishing a book takes two things: Hard Work and Finance.  With your donations and our hard work, In Her Words: 25 Interviews with Kick-Ass Women in Arts & Entertainment will be a best-selling book and artistic resource for insanely talented women.


We have estimated our fund raising goal of $5,000 for the following publishing needs and other unforeseen expenses that arise:

 

  • Photography
  • Website Development and Maintenance
  • Publicity and Marketing
  • Actual Publishing Expenses
  • Editing and Formatting
  • Graphic Designer
  • Travel & Promotional Expenses


We will also update this page with weekly In Her Words book project goals--physical and financial. 


If we do not meed our funding goal, we will hold bake sales, run errands and have car washes in our driveways in order to finish raising the capital to publish this ground-breaking book.  Every person who donated will receive their donor goodies, even if we fall short of the campaign total.


What will happen if we go over and beyond our initial goal of $5,000?  We'd love to put the cash towards an official book launch that EVERY PERSON WHO FINANCIALLY CONTRIBUTED will receive an invite to attend or to one of our favorite charities (depending on overage amount).  Pretty cool, huh?


Take a moment to read the right hand side of this page, where you'll see the amazing donor goodies we put together just for you. Take a look right now and decide which level is right for you.  (Perk awards for donations will be distributed after campaign ends, although certain perks like the limited-edition Cover Art postcards and Shout-outs will be distributed as donations come in.)


Other Ways You Can Help

We are grateful for any help you can give us in spreading the word about the book.

Here are some suggestions:

  • post a link to this page on your Facebook and Twitter;
  • write a post about In Her Words: 25 Interviews with Kick-Ass Women in Arts & Entertainment on your blog;
  • give us a mention in your organization's newsletter.

We are also available for interviews about the book and the project. You can contact us (about that or anything else) by posting a message here or by emailing InHerWordsBook (at) Live (dot) com.

story:
A Little About Me and My Goals

    I have always loved to travel and plan for it to remain a large part of my life. But I don't want myself to be the only one who benefits from my experiences, I want to share them, allow others to see and learn what travel has shown me, and my best mediums for such sharing are through writing and photography.  For the past couple of months I've been backpacking California and my eyes have really been opened to the vast amount of opportunity I have in front of me.  On April 13th, I turn 21 and it seems a good time to set some new goals and focus my wanderings. Sure, "everyone" wants to be a travel writer.  Get paid to see the world and write about it?! What a great far off dream, right?  Maybe not so far off.  While my skills in those areas could use some direction, I can make that happen!  The people who get what they want out of life are the ones who go for it and aren't afraid to ask for help when needed.  That's where you come in.  

 

    Matador, one of the world's largest online travel communities has created MatadorU, a set of online programs for travel writing, photography, and filmmaking. The course is split into 12 chapters with weekly tests as well as bonus modules with such topics as the art of interviews and personal branding. The program has a lot of positive reviews and the networking opportunities are wonderful.  They really push students to achieve in the field.  There are opportunities of publication throughout the program as well as press trips and even a paid live in writing stint in Belize.  Good incentive to take the classes seriously.  Here's what National Geographic Traveler has to say about MatadorU:

 “Matador is one of the most important publishing venues we look to find talented new travel writers and photographers.” - Keith Bellows, National Geographic Traveler

    During the program you can follow my work and travels on my Matador travel blog, the link to which I would make available as soon as it gets set up.

 

Check it out for yourself! http://matadoru.com/


Funds Needed and Contribution Bonuses

    The Travel Writing and Photography programs cost $350 each.  However, should I do both I would get $100 off.  So that's $600 for both courses, not too bad a deal, eh?  The main goal is to do both, with the travel writing at the forefront of importance.  Even if I do not reach the goal amount all money raised will go into one or both of the programs. Every little bit counts.

As you are such generous folk and travel is a thing to be shared, I would like to share it with you.  So as a thank you for your contributions you can receive fun gifts like postcards while I travel and photos from my trips.  I want you to be a part of what you are helping make happen.

Short on Cash?

  Me too, thus the fundraiser.  But you can still help out!  Spread the word through social media and IndieGoGo's sharing tools.  Help in any form is appreciated!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Dallas J. Moore.  I have been writing poetry since I was 15 years old.  During the past few years, I've lost a couple of very important people in my life, which helped inspire me to start writing more. I decided to compile the poems I wrote to create a book of my poetry.  I've found a strong passion for writing and want to share it with others.  It has helped me cope with loss and hope that it will speak to others who are also facing life challenges.

What We Need & What You Get

I am seeking $2,000, which will help me self publish my first book of poetry, allow me to have sufficient copies printed in order to stock local book stores, create a digital format of the book (kindle, nook, iBook), and pay the artist who helped me with the cover and those who have been kind enough to edit, without promise of compensation. 

The goal of this project is to reach a specific goal. Because of that, there is no small piece - any donation and person matters in this. I don't know if I can do it all alone. I want people who help this project feel good about helping me and know that I don't take their time, energy and money lightly. Any donation from anyone is equal in my eyes. 

All donations to this campaign will receive a hand written thank you note from me. I feel its very important to express my thanks for your help in this adventure in my life.

  • $5.00 gets you a hand written thank you note from me.

  • $20.00 gets you a hand written thank you and a public thank you on a special blog post on my website.

  • $40.00 gets you a copy of the book, a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note.

  • $70.00 gets you a copy of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note.

  • $100.00 gets you a Chaos Mind t-shirt, a copy of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note.

  • $250.00 gets you acknowledgements in the book - Chaos Mind: Inpiration from Moments of Desperation, a Chaos Mind t-shirt, a copy of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you. 

  • $500.00 gets you a framed poem (not in the book) and a phone call where I will read poems from Chaos Mind: Inspiration from Moments of Desperation to you, acknowledgements in the book, a Chaos Mind t-shirt, 2 copies of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note.

  • $1,000.00 a poem written and dedicated to you, (this poem will be framed and mailed to you, and featured on my website), mentioned in the acknowledgements in the book, a phone call where I will read poems from Chaos Mind: Inspiration from Moments of Desperation,  a Chaos Mind t-shirt, 2 copies of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note. 

 If I do not reach my goal of $2,000.00 I will first pay my artist and those who help me with editing and layout of the book. With the money left over I will order however many books I can, and make them avaliable on Kindle, Nook, and iBook. 

The Impact

I have been writing for 14 years. I never thought about making it more than what it was, a way to express myself, and share how I see the world around me. Now, I've realized that it's time to share myself with the world, and to encourage others to share how they feel, what they think, and how they see the world. I want to empower people to have a voice and use writing and poetry as a way to cope with the ups and downs life throws at you. I would love to be a starting place, where someone can relate to how others feel, and to promote the understanding that it's okay to feel whatever you feel. It's also okay to express how you feel, in a positive and productive way, and to create and experience.

I have been involved in raising money and awareness for a Children's Cancer Connection  while I was attending college. I also started the Des Moines Zombie Walk in 2009 to help raise money and awarness for Central Iowa Shelther & Services, focused on helping the homeless in Des Moines, Iowa. In 2011, I helped found a non-profit, Thongs for Him, to help men battling cancer, after losing my dad in 2010. 

I have never asked anyone for anything, even after my wife and I got married in late 2009 and we were both laid off. I started my own business to support us and my wife's dream of going back to school to become a teacher. 

I have always found a way. This is a new project and I've become a new person. I know there are others who feel and think the way I do. Maybe you do. I would love to be able to connect with them, share my story, and encourage them to share and write theirs. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help me fund this project, that's okay. You can share this campaign with your family and friends. You can tell others you know who write poetry, write in a daily journal, or just enjoy reading. You can tell those you know who have experienced loss that I have as well, maybe we would be able to relate with one another. 

  • Feel free to share this campaign with anyone you think would enjoy it.
  • Write a blog post about how much you love or hate poetry and include my campaign.
  • Find me on Twitter @mrdallasjmoore and tell me what you think about my poetry, my campaign, and feel free to ask me anything. Connect with me there. I would love to talk with you and get to know you. 
  • Use the share tools on Indiegogo to help spread the word! 

Thank you so much. I am so thankful and excited for this opportunity. I hope you will join me.

-Dallas J. Moore

March 2013

$500.00 gets you a framed poem (not in the book) and a phone call where I will read poems from Chaos Mind: Inspiration from Moments of Desperation to you, acknowledgements in the book, a Chaos Mind t-shirt, 2 copies of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note.
$1,000.00 a poem written and dedicated to you, (this poem will be framed and mailed to you, and featured on my website), mentioned in the acknowledgements in the book, a phone call where I will read poems from Chaos Mind: Inspiration from Moments of Desperation,  a Chaos Mind t-shirt, 2 copies of the book (before its release date), a public thank you in a special blog post on my website, and a hand written thank you note. 

 If I do not reach my goal of $2,000.00 I will first pay my artist and those who help me with editing and layout of the book. With the money left over I will order however many books I can, and make them avaliable on Kindle, Nook, and iBook. 


The Impact
I have been writing for 14 years. I never thought about making it more than what it was, a way to express myself, and share how I see the world around me. Now, I've realized that it's time to share myself with the world, and to encourage others to share how they feel, what they think, and how they see the world. I want to empower people to have a voice and use writing and poetry as a way to cope with the ups and downs life throws at you. I would love to be a starting place, where someone can relate to how others feel, and to promote the understanding that it's okay to feel whatever you feel. It's also okay to express how you feel, in a positive and productive way, and to create and experience.
I have been involved in raising money and awareness for a Children's Cancer Connection  while I was attending college. I also started the Des Moines Zombie Walk in 2009 to help raise money and awarness for Central Iowa Shelther & Services, focused on helping the homeless in Des Moines, Iowa. In 2011, I helped found a non-profit, Thongs for Him, to help men battling cancer, after losing my dad in 2010. 
I have never asked anyone for anything, even after my wife and I got married in late 2009 and we were both laid off. I started my own business to support us and my wife's dream of going back to school to become a teacher. 
I have always found a way. This is a new project and I've become a new person. I know there are others who feel and think the way I do. Maybe you do. I would love to be able to connect with them, share my story, and encourage them to share and write theirs. 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't help me fund this project, that's okay. You can share this campaign with your family and friends. You can tell others you know who write poetry, write in a daily journal, or just enjoy reading. You can tell those you know who have experienced loss that I have as well, maybe we would be able to relate with one another. 

Feel free to share this campaign with anyone you think would enjoy it.
Write a blog post about how much you love or hate poetry and include my campaign.
Find me on Twitter @mrdallasjmoore and tell me what you think about my poetry, my campaign, and feel free to ask me anything. Connect with me there. I would love to talk with you and get to know you. 
Use the share tools on Indiegogo to help spread the word! 

Thank you so much. I am so thankful and excited for this opportunity. I hope you will join me.
-Dallas J. Moore
March 2013

story:
This is Max Perkins, the founder & Grand Poobah of DEEP KISS PRESS, and I'm here to ask for your money. People like lists, so here's one to explain why DEEP KISS PRESS is like nothing else out there in the world of publishing, and when you've read it you will see that we are unique, authentic, and just may be the future of publishing. (And then you will be so inspired that you'll write us a check to help us grow and flourish!)

WHY DEEP KISS PRESS ROCKS:

1. We're truly alternative. We just don't say we are while secretly wanting to be offered a scrap from the table of the big publishing conglomerates. (Refer to our website to see how badass we are! See below...)

2. Our books are unlike anything out there. Our covers are works of art and the words inside these covers are real, true, impassioned, and harken back to another era when Literature still existed and mattered, with all of its unpredictability, experimentation, and artistic vision, before the Publishing Industry (some might say dinosaur on the verge of extinction) decided to become an assembly line for bestsellers-soon-to-be-made-into-major-motion-pictures and a purveyor of uniformity.

3. We celebrate discovering amazing writers and artists and then we help them to make their books as awesome as they can be so we can then put them out into the world, because the world IS a better place with a little more beauty, a little more honesty, a little more artistic integrity in a world of soul-selling and bottom-line driven conformity. What's being offered by mainstream publishing is only that which can be fit into a teeny-tiny hole the size of a pea and we REFUSE to whittle down our enormous log to the size of a toothpick. Instead we take our enormous log and bash the hell out of their teeny-tiny hole!

WHY WE NEED YOUR $$$:

1. DEEP KISS PRESS is a labor of love by all those involved, but love only goes so far in business, and eventually people need to get paid. Our award-winning design team AMERIKAN HIPSTER (who comes up with our amazing award-winning covers) have so far generously donated their time and talent, as have most of the artists whose work we've used. But we would like to go to the next step. Time is money, and everyone involved have worked untold hours for free or for nominal compensation but we want to reward our amazing collaborators--our artists, cover designers, editors, layout specialists, photographers, and consultants--because they deserve to get paid for their incredible work, and we want to keep them happy and inspire them to even more amazing work!

2. We'd also like to offer our authors an advance. Right now we give them a box of books but we'd love to include a check in that box as well to make their day and keep the talent happy!

3. Nuts & bolts. We need more of both. We want to upgrade our computer--maybe even have more than one! We want to upgrade our software. Right now we are renting the Adobe Suite including InDesign and Photoshop on a monthly basis. We'd love to purchase it outright.

4. Advertising & Social Networking. We would like to hire someone to maintain all of the social networking sites so DEEP KISS PRESS can expand its presence and reach out to everyone. This way we will be able to discover more amazing artists and more people will discover us and buy our books! And we also want to advertise in key publications, but advertising is very expensive, ESPECIALLY for a small business.

So there it is.
And if you need further convincing then go right now to our website and you'll see why we are unlike any place else, and then please offer us your generous support! It isn't often that one can be a part of something that is so full of passion and conviction that it truly inspires. DEEP KISS PRESS is such a place!

Thanks for you consideration.

www.deepkisspress.com
